text: We are a family of zoo lovers, and although this is not our favorite zoo, you have to check it off your list. I highly encourage splurging on an animal encounter like the hippos. Even the extra $2 bird food is worth it to have a bird sit on your finger. You do have to stand in a long concession line to get it though. Unlike other zoos, you can't take coolers in there, but waters and small snacks are allowed. Our family did just fine in March with a meal before the zoo, snacks & water during, and a meal after.

text: This has been one of the best sanctuaryâ€™s Iâ€™ve visited in Awhile. Our experience was amazing. We went on a cool Monday and most to all the animals we out for the public to see. All the big cats have Relatively large enclosures and all seem to be healthy. One of our favorite parts was when we got to see some of their caring staff members assist the zoos foxâ€™s in painting with their little paws. The foxes were very excited and seemed to loved it. title: Austin Zoo

text: Had my daughters birthday here and it was worth every bit of the money! We rented the peacock pavilion, pre purchased feed bags for the kids to feed the livestock and opted to add on the "animal experience" where a staff member came over with a box turtle, a tarantula and a ball python to teach the kids about them. I recommend coming early when the feedings are going on as the animals are way more active and the temperature is nice. We love it!
title: Austin Zoo

text:
This was a great experience.. when we first got there it must have been nap time because not one animal was awake that we could see so we just walked around and took in the scenery and by the time we   got to a point where we had to turn around everybody was awake . And we figured out that it was now feeding time... Very cool to watch the animals come out of their slumber to let the humans know it's time to eat! All the enclosures were large and clean with plenty of stimulation for the animals so that was great to see...
They also have plaques or signs on most of the enclosures with a backstory as to how the animal ended up there, if there was a story to be told. All in all a very good experience and super affordable.
title: Austin Zoo

text:
It's a small zoo but worth the trip. I recommend going once a little warmer. We went when it's a bit cold so some of the animals weren't out. But we still had a good time and I honestly like the outdoor feel. It's a lovely place and a great time for the family. It felt more natural for the animals.

Edit: Also just wanna say going during winter is very worth it!!! It's still a great place to go :) lovely.
title: Austin Zoo

text:
I'm giving it 4 stars because the staff was very nice and it seems they really do love the animals and what they do there.

The problem is it's not a zoo it's more like a wild life exhibit. I think calling it a zoo makes people show up and be disappointed. We were disappointed but still had a nice time.

If you want to see a animal exhibit then please go there are animals there and the staff is friendly and the gift shop is really nice we spent about $60 in it but I think it was fairly priced. It's really about the kids and they enjoyed themselves.
title: Austin Zoo

text: Definitely worth the drive! While not as big and sprawling as the San Diego or Denver Zoo, the Austin Zoo has a cool selection of animals that the kids loved and we're able to actually see the animals a lot closer then they would of been anywhere else. I've never been able to see multiple peacocks up close and personal before! The park was very clean with lots of trees for shade. The staff really made this place shine as EVERYONE said hello or good morning, honestly it was surreal how friendly everyone was!
title: Austin Zoo

text:
This little zoo is great! We went here on a weekday, so it wasn't very crowded. The zoo is a rescue zoo, so all the animals are surrendered or given to them by other zoos or state facilities.
Every enclosure has a sign with some information about the animal species and also the backstory of this animal specific which I love. I think this provides a lot of education to people.
I love the lions, they were so beautiful, I wish they had a more engaging enclosure same with the bears ( which they are renovating).
There's also a train to see some additional animals which can't be seen by foot.
This zoo is great for all ages, to see the animals and learn about their species and backstories.
title: Austin Zoo

text: Wonderful zoo! It is a non profit rescue zoo so it is a bit small but that makes it nice to do with younger kids. You donâ€™t miss anything but you donâ€™t need all day to be there. There was good tree coverage which helped keep the temperature down since itâ€™s pretty hot and sunny in August in Texas. The terrain is a little rocky but we did manage to do the whole thing with our stroller and no real issues. Just be  prepared that it is not a smooth path. Beautiful, well taken care of animals.
title: Austin Zoo

text: I had a lot of fun here. There were lots of unique animals. A lot of them were tired from the summer heat but so were we. It's a fun place to walk around. We turned our backs to the white tiger and she jumped at us. It was startling but pretty cool at the same time. It may not be as paved and built up as zoos like the San Antonio and Houston Zoo but it's has it's own charm that I really enjoyed. It was amazing to be able to see a rescue zoo! We got to see many of the animals eating and relaxing, it was a really great experience. I would recommend to anyone who lives in the area.
title: Austin Zoo

text: My husband and I decided to stop in at the zoo while we were in Austin and had a little extra time to spare. I love that this is more of a rescue facility than a traditional zoo. It's so sad that most of these animals needed rescuing because of some stupid human that thought they would make a pet of a wild animal but it is wonderful that this facility exists to take them in! I loved being able to visit the Galapagos tortoises!
title: Austin Zoo

text:
Lions, tigers and kids oh my! Austin zoo is prides themselves in giving rescued animals a chance for a new life. They take them in, feed and care for them.

They have an area where you can feed goats & llamas. Peacocks strut their colorful, eye-catching feathers around the park.

Itâ€™s a perfect venue for your childâ€™s birthday party! You can reserve a private room and even learn about animals & pet one!

Donâ€™t forget to take a ride on the train with your little ones! Itâ€™s always a big hit!
title: Austin Zoo

text: Went 30mins after opening it was not that busy or packed so it was nice to walk around. We had a wagon but decided to leave it at the entrance and walk. First time going here and for my toddler to go to a zoo and see animals. They have free roaming peacocks which was really neat you seen them all over the place. It is a sanctuary so not super big or have a lot of different animals (hippos, rhino, flamingo, ect.) Still for kids who never seen animals or aren't keen on walking around for hours like bigger zoos this is perfect still enjoyable.
title: Austin Zoo

text: Great little gem in Austin! It is so cute and really seems to focus on the animals and their wellbeing. Friendly and caring staff. Reasonable pricing and a lot of great exhibits to see!
title: Austin Zoo

text:
10/10 experience!!!! Well worth the money. We spent about 2 hours here and definitely couldâ€™ve stayed longer.

Since thereâ€™s so many trees, it was shaded basically the entire zoo, which is a must in the Texas sun.

Love that this is a rescue zoo and their conservation mission. We loved reading about where each animal came from.

Also, since the animals are rescued, they werenâ€™t hiding like they do in normal zoos. We went as soon as they open, and everyone was out and about in their exhibits.

Our favorite part was definitely feeding the goats and alpacas but it was also amazing seeing lions and cougars that close up!

We will definitely be back and will be bringing friends!!
title: Austin Zoo

text: Nice little zoo! Love that itâ€™s all rescue animals and so many different species to see. Loved feeding the different animals too. Defiantly a place to see!
title: Austin Zoo

text: I hardly ever leave bad reviews but compared to San Antonio zoo this place was such a let down. Most of the animals are all caged up so you canâ€™t really see them. We went on pretty chilly day and all the tropical birds were sharing one little heat lamp and you could tell they were so distressed. The animals looked pretty miserable to be honest. The only parts we enjoyed were the feeding of the farm animals which you canâ€™t even do like at a petting zoo you have to feed them through the fence. The train and the conductor were the best part. He was super nice and pretty funny. He offered to take our pics which I appreciated. But if your not from Austin and thinking about making the trip out hereâ€¦donâ€™t. Seriously the snake farm in new branfuels was in better shape and condition than this. Drive out to San Antonio and go to a real zoo or if your looking for something more hands on drive to Johnson city to go to the exotic resort zoo, there are a lot more animals there and they look much more attended too. We left this place pretty sad.
title: Austin Zoo

text: This zoo is actually not bad, it's a very zen like zoo. I went on a day where it wasn't crowded at all but all the good animals were inside. I went around twice to check on the lions, bears and tigers. So the 2nd time around the lions and bears were out but that white tiger was in chill mood in the hut. Nice place to take the kids and learn about animals.
title: Austin Zoo

text: Great place for kids, even the little ones. They have a fun train, animal feeding, peacocks walking around. The animals seem to be well taken care of. There's lions, a tiger, wolves, bears... basically almost anything you'd want to see in a zoo. Also the price of admission, the train tickets, gift shop etc. were reasonably priced. Also, all the zoo caretakers were so nice and accomodating.
title: Austin Zoo

text: Great little zoo!  We really enjoyed it and loved the rescue based mission. We did get a membership for our family of 4 as we intend to come back at least once and it made financial sense to do so.  It was still pretty hot here in Texas so most of the animals were sleeping in the shade but we still enjoyed the hill country landscape and reading their stories. Looking forward to coming back!
title: Austin Zoo

text: Visited in January on a cloudy day and most of the park is shut down.  Train not running,  animals in due to cold. Areas closed off for unknown reasons.  Wouldn't recommend for elderly or handicapped visitors, the walkways are uneven and muddy in places. Loved the lions,  and the Bengal tiger who made a showing for us (gorgeous). More of a refuge than a zoo.
title: Austin Zoo

text: What an amazing little zoo. I highly recommend going when they open because the animals are more active. We got to see the lions, tigers and bears up super close. To see those majestic animals that close was epic.
title: Austin Zoo

text: Such an awesome place. I've been hearing from friends that not many people know about this zoo. If you have young kids, bring them here and have a great time. All the animals are rescue animals and are fun to look at. The zoo staff are friendly. There is also toy train ride we can enjoy.
title: Austin Zoo

text: There were not as many animals as we'd hoped to see. There were areas closed off to protect the most vulnerable animals during the pandemic which I support, however it was hard to see several exhibits because of this. The exotic animals were beautiful and that made the trip worth it. I am giving 4 stars because they are a rescue zoo, and take great care of their animals.
title: Austin Zoo

text:
A rescue zoo so I will no give less than 5 stars for what they do for these neglected animals. ðŸ’– thank you for your service.
That being said, great for kids but pretty sad as most of them were "pets" who were abandoned and major stress and mental suffering was clearly present. Left me feeling down a bit. Amazing galopagose tortoise and other animals too.
title: Austin Zoo

text:
This is not a flashy zoo, and it is really off the beaten path. You won't see extremely exotic critters. They have lemurs, monkeys, tortoises, snakes, parrots, bears, lions, tigers and a petting zoo section.

Why would you come here, then? Because you'll feel good patronizing a place with its mission. They rescue animals and give them a better life.

I like a zoo that not only cares for their animals, but also tries to make sure people know how hard it is to care for parrots. I like a zoo whose staff connect with the patrons. And folks, I loved the alpacas and prairie dogs as well as the other critters I listed. Recommended.
title: Austin Zoo

text: I liked that the animals were very interactive and alert. Very neat small sized zoo.
title: Austin Zoo

text: Had some free time on a Sunday morning and thought we'd check out the zoo in our new city. Now we're from San Diego (home to the World Famous San Diego Zoo) so we know great zoos. As my teenager daughter said, it's like a petting zoo. This is not your typical zoo. They rescue animals (there was a three-legged fox there). The walkways are dirt. The variety of animals is limited. I'd say this is a great place for families with young kids. It's a couple hour adventure for young ones. We walked through in under an hour.
title: Austin Zoo

text: The animals looked well cared for and that made us all very happy. The peacocks were wondering about freely and let us get really close up pics!ðŸ’“ The little "big" cat was actually purring and talking with us. It was a great time. Thank you Austin Zoo!

text: I enjoyed my experience! I thought the place was really cute and the employees were very nice and helpful. This is the most Iâ€™ve seen animals interact with each other and guests.
title: Austin Zoo

text:
Came here based on reviews and donâ€™t understand what the hype was all about. Itâ€™s a pricey ticket for what it is. text: Small zoo, animals kept in very tight closures. It was okay and the train ride was fun but the zoo itself was not that great.

text: Great little zoo. Perfect for taking small kids. Lots of shade trees for hot days.

text: It's great for little kids, my granddaughter loves the train ride! Bring a picnic. Will definitely return when it cools down some!

text: My 2 and 7 year olds had a great time looking at all the animals, feeding livestock, and riding the train.  The gift shop was also a hit!
title: Austin Zoo

text: Our visit to the Austin zoo was enjoyable and there are plenty of animals to see. Lots of shade helps with the sun and the pathways are easy to navigate. The staff are friendly and the animals appear well cared for. There's a train and plenty of kids' activities. The zoo does show some wear and is in need of upkeep here and there  but overall it's a nice place for a stroll on a beautiful day.
title: Austin Zoo

text: It was a small zoo, but my kids enjoyed every bit of it! You can visit the entire place within 30 mins..we went on a week day evening, it was less people! And people who work there were extremely nice and can tell that they love their job! We enjoyed seeing, beautiful peacocks, monkeys, goats, lamas, lion & tiger!
title: Austin Zoo

text: Wonderful zoo and rescue sanctuary. We love the capybara encounter! So fun! We saw lots of cats, birds, goats, ostriches, peacocks, bears and lizards. Highly recommend!
title: Austin Zoo

text: I wasn't expecting AZA zoo level fare, and I was neither disappointed nor thrilled with my visit. Animal enclosures seem to be a decent enough size in general, but many are concrete substrate and seem a little bare-bones as far as enrichment. I did enjoy getting to see the Galapagos tortoises so closely, but as a whole it was simply a nice visit but not one I'd be champing at the bit to return to.
title: Austin Zoo

text: Check your expectations. This is a rescue zoo, not a full-fledged corporate-sponsored zoo like the big ones. They have a great variety for being a small sanctuary. The paths are dirt and gravel, so wear close-toed shoes. If you or someone you are with is in a wheelchair, it may be a little rough, but we saw a few people in standard and motorized chairs. There are about 50 peacocks free roaming and in habitats. Also, it is the spring, so expect some frisky animals. The big cats can spray you if you get too close or they think you are a threat. There is a train that is about $5/rider. It is a nice little ride around the back of some of the paddocks. Every single staff member was super friendly and helpful and knowledgable. Though they donâ€™t have concessions, they do have vending machines throughout the park. There are a few regular bathrooms that are wheelchair accessible. There are also quite a few portable toilets to the right of the entrance. The wolves, cougars, lions, and tiger were all big draws. The bears were not out when we went. This zoo is out in ranch country (started as a goat farm). Keep in mind the roads are curvy and tight.
title: Austin Zoo

text: It was a small zoo but it felt like a sanctuary- unlike other zoo it didn't seem commercialized with vendors. There was shade from the sun and rain. We saw 3 legged pig and a blind owl. I'm glad we came and saw these injured animals. And the vegetables the tortoises were eating were so fresh and not bruised.
title: Austin Zoo

text: We had so much fun! The white tiger was so pretty! We loved seeing the baby peacocks flowing their mama's!  I'd suggest wearing closed toe shoes as the paths are gravel.
title: Austin Zoo

text: Booked the capybara experience at the zoo. Got to spend time sitting with them and feeding them, and learning all about them from the zoo keepers. Super cool!
title: Austin Zoo

text: A sprawling park with plenty to see and do. The staff is very accommodating. We went on a Thursday and it was very very quiet which was unexpected but pleasant.
title: Austin Zoo

text: Worth the drive. Not very big but it is a non-profit and rescue zoo which made me happy. Love me some animals.
title: Austin Zoo

text: Had a great time at the zoo with my son, It is a very informational zoo, the workers enjoyed Answering questions, they also looked at home with the animals they are working with. I would surly come back another time.
title: Austin Zoo

text: Didn't know the place,  was beautiful place. If you are lucky you'll have a close encounter with peacocks.
title: Austin Zoo

text: My kids had fun. Decent petting zoo.. some exhibits closed. Somewhat grown up and untended. Expensive for what it is.. Helping a cause I guess.. All animals are rescues I was told.
title: Austin Zoo

text: We love this Zoo. Gets busy around noon. My kid loves the train. Takes about two hours to get through the whole Zoo.
title: Austin Zoo

text: Whatâ€™s a great hole in the wall type zoo the animals seem happy , you can even feed and meet some of them. Definitely a great experience
title: Austin Zoo

text: Decent for a private zoo, but it can't keep up with public zoos. Austin doesn't have a public zoo, so it's the best option if your kids want the experience. All rescue animals, which is nice.
title: Austin Zoo

text: Nice little Zoo. Love the peacocks all over the zoo. They are rowdy fellas. A good 2 hours is plenty to enjoy it. Everyone was really good about keeping their masks on. Wear sneakers because no pavement here, all dirt walkways with rocks. Toilets were broken. Skidocans were disgustingly full. Never have I ever! At least the zoo was nice. Free petting area was a hit with everyone. The reptile area and bear ðŸ» ðŸ§¸area were  down for service. Beautiful birds, even a little rainbow ðŸŒˆ  colored one. I am now a bird fan.

text:
Update 2: still great!
Update: don't remember why I have put 3 stars two years ago, so I am updating rating to 5 stars. We have membership, and my son absolutely loves this zoo! Check out the train as well - it's a must!
title: Austin Zoo

text: Great little place with a variety of animals! There's a feeding zone where goats come rushing to you at the sight of food. There's also a little train that goes through the surrounding region of the zoo. Wish it went through more exhibits of animals but hey, it was a nice and calm little ride!
title: Austin Zoo

text: We love bringing the kiddos here for a few hours. It is a great place for an impromptu day trip for our family of 5!
title: Austin Zoo

text: Loved this zoo, great place to bring your kids. There's such a variety of animals and they're all rescued. I had a great time even one of the foxes here had my name! They also let their peacocks run free around the zoo which is pretty cool.
title: Austin Zoo

text: Not a very big zoo, but very nice.  All of the animals are rescue animals.  The animal enclosures are not as big or as elaborate as other zoos, but the animals look well cared for.  There's a pretty big area where you can feed the goats, sheep, and alpacas.
title: Austin Zoo

text: Very nice zoo, even with cold weather 50F and some rain we were able to enjoy it.
title: Austin Zoo

text:
This zoo is located in a natural scenery in what I would describe as a forest like.  The walking paths are dirt and gravel that were very slippery at times.
Wear walking shoes and don't forget the sunscreen.  They do sell some in the gift shop but it left white stuff all over.
The enclosures were bare and some seemed small for the type of animals they held.  For the hot day it would be nice to see more shade room they can enjoy where we can see them.beyter instead of them being inside where they were out of sight.  We were able to observe feeding times with some of the animals and the keepers seemed to be invested and treat them well.  Some areas are under construction at this time and it was difficult to see some of the exhibits. It wasn't very big which for what they offered was enough.
title: Austin Zoo

text: Great place to take the kids.  The train is a big hit with my kids.
title: Austin Zoo

text:
Make sure you catch one of the the hourly train rides during your adventure! Itâ€™s a great way to â€œfindâ€ an ostrich and see the rolling hills. Grab some feed for the barnyard critters & enjoy the sights of free range peacocks.

There are a few â€œoff limitsâ€ from the pandemic, but still a good time for families. When you arrive youâ€™ll use an alternate entrance & you can honestly enjoy this entire zoo without ever stepping foot inside a building. (Please note this also means consider the potty needs of your party beforehand.)
title: Austin Zoo

text: This place was a bit of a disappointment. Although, staff was very friendly and working hard. Many vacant areas with no animals. Reptiles all closed down. There were white wolves, but you couldn't get to them because areas were closed off. Lions, monkeys, and bears were cool. Did not see panther, tiger, zebras, or ostriches. A lot of construction, not many animals. Many goats, birds, tortoises, peacocks to see here. Train was also not running. Wouldn't recommend at this time. Snake farm is a better experience.
title: Austin Zoo

text: We had a wonderful visit with 4 great nieces/nephews ages 7 to 11.
title: Austin Zoo

text: This little Zoo is impressive but it needs some TLC. I'm sure the pandemic didn't help. It's under construction and I hope it gets back up to it's full potential. It just feels a bit tired. I went here with my 4 year old and it's the perfect size for an afternoon walk. I would recommend and can't wait to come back when the renovations are finished.
title: Austin Zoo

text: We had a nice time at the zoo. I loved that every plate describing the species had their names and birthdays - very cute! The large cats were very majestic. The train could be improved with running more often than once an hour on high volume days. The animals looked mostly health. We did watch a goat get tackled by the workers and it  looked like they were forcing some medicine - understandable but probably more appropriate time to do it or heads up to the people right by the enclosure as it looked super distressed/ scared and for some of the kids that was a little scary to watch.
title: Austin Zoo

text: I loved it here! This place is slightly small but so much and so great. I saw almost all (94%) the animals and some places were roped off (due to COVID) but they had it so you could get a close to the animals as possible. The placards they had to show us where the animals came from and their names were great and I really love that they were rescue animals that means a lot to people! The staff was super friendly and answered the questions even the ones that were about the animals ar the vet. I would love to come and get closer to the animals and bring my family, it was a great experience. Again I really love they are rescues ðŸ’œðŸ’œðŸ’œðŸ’œðŸ’œ
title: Austin Zoo

text: The only reason I give three stars is because my kids liked it. I was comparing it to the Ft. Worth, Dallas, and Oklahoma City zoos and it is just not anywhere as nice as those and it still cost my family of four $57. The reptile house was closed (big bummer because my kids love snakes), the bathrooms were closed (porta-potties) and they told me the reason reptile house was closed was it's too small inside for covid reasons... but you can still go in the gift shop. I was annoyed that they make all visitors over age of 2 wear a mask at all times... in an outdoor, plenty of room setting! The zoo has no paved walkways and water has washed lots of gullies where I almost turned my ankle. I was not given a map and the signage was lacking so we just wandered. Tickets are sold from a trailer. I found the animal enclosures to be difficult to see animals through. The white tiger and peacocks were cool.
title: Austin Zoo

text:
For being Austin, we expected the zoo to have better selections. Most of the places are closedown. Staff is constantly walking to make sure you wear the mask although the Texas Gov agreed for outdoors to be a free mask zone.
But the staff kept trying to enforced it on my toddler (2 years old) . My daughterâ€™s mask fits her a little bit loose, so the lady was asking to put it more tighter although it was covering her nose.
Thereâ€™s no Giraffes ðŸ¦’.
Thereâ€™s more of a bird ðŸ¦¢ selection, monkeys ðŸ’, goats ðŸAnd ðŸ– pig (be careful with the pig)

I believed itâ€™s overpriced for the few animals you get to see. But if you want to see it for yourself then go for it. Lots of construction.
title: Austin Zoo

text:
Due to Covid19, orange netting is surrounding much of the exhibits. Please don't let this deter you! This does not obstruct viewing, only for extra distance purposes for the animals. The old admissions building is no longer open. You will now walk up to a small outside trailer to show proof of online ticket purchase, which is preferred. By the way, NO CASH.. just debit/credit cards are being used.

This day we visited around 3pm when many animals were active. Zoo keepers fed most of the animals while we watched. Our 3 year old enjoyed feeding the goats, sheep, deer and Llamas. Brown bag feed bags are $3 which you will find in the now outside souvenir shop next to the reptile exhibit. We all also rode the train for $5 a person. The scenery/displays on the train ride could use some improvement but I understand the money raised here goes back in to keeping those sweet animals happy and healthy. Concession stand is closed, but they offer a small selection of chips and drinks in the souvenir shop. You can bring your own refreshments in, just no sharing with the animals. Oh! And watch out for the beautiful roaming free peacocks. They are mesmerizing!

Overall, we love visiting Austin Zoo. We visit 2-3 times a year. It's small but worth seeing the smile on your kiddos face.
title: Austin Zoo

text: Was visiting from Atlanta and decided to take my daughter and her cousins, they seemed to enjoy it,, though not what I expected. It's an okay place for the price. Very few animals, the train goes in circles and all you is is the zebra and ostrich. No toilet( not sure if its covid related). Animals are dirty, and some are wounded.
title: Austin Zoo

text: The Austin Zoo is a really cute and rustic zoo. Surprisingly good number of animals that all seemed very happy and well taken care of. Really enjoyed the bear exhibit and canâ€™t wait to see its forthcoming expansion. Definitely worth a visit.
title: Austin Zoo

text:
Small zoo but perfect size for tiny tots! They don't get too tired, there are no scary critters and there's a small train ride perfect for them. They can feed goats, llamas etc.

Pro tip: Smaller goats on the right of the red barn are more gentle, best for tinier and shy babies. Get a bag of feed from the red barn.

Deducted a star for missing animals and no note about why they're missing. Overall a great experience and will definitely go back with my one year old!
title: Austin Zoo

text: It was late in the afternoon. I would suggest getting there early as possible. Most of the big exotic animals were inside their boxes staying cool. They have a  train you can ride for a small fee and it takes you around the trails. It is fully funded by donations. The animals have been injured or displaced so it is where they will stay. Peacocks roam free on the property. We enjoyed it a lot. But it was 102 in the sun.
title: Austin Zoo

text: I really enjoyed the wildlife rescue zoo. At first I was expecting a typical city zoo, but realized Austin doesnâ€™t have a city zoo. This privately owned and funded zoo is doing a great job of providing homes for rescued animals. I enjoyed learning about the animals, but I especially loved reading about their stories. Some of the stories really tugged at your heart strings. I noticed they had some company sponsors, which is great too. They are doing a great job for being privately funded. If you need a place to sit while at the zoo I would recommend bringing a chair, because all the benches are blocked off due to COVID. They also require masks while outside even with social distancing so be prepared for the heat with a mask on. I would recommend bribing water. They do have a vending machine for water if needed. All the animals were well cared for and I felt like my ticket went to a good cause. Just come with the mindset of animal rescue and you will enjoy this zoo. Oh almost forgot they do have a train ride for $5 per person on top of your ticket where you can see more animals.
title: Austin Zoo

text: Entrance fee is high for a zoo of this size. You can spend a maximum of 1 hour. I like that the zoo is taking care of the animals very well. They look happy and healthy ðŸ‘
title: Austin Zoo

text: Great place for rescued animals that can't be released back into the wild.
title: Austin Zoo

text: Cute small zoo, they have a lot of places under construction, can't wait to see how it turns out! Great place to spend time with family.
title: Austin Zoo

text:
Came here for my friends kids birthday and it was super fabulous! I enjoy going to the zoo, this is a different type of zoo than most people are used too. The zoo is smaller than most, but it's also more laid back and casual to me. It is more of a re-homing facility for animals who have a long back story. They are definitely doing good work here! All the animals seem to be enjoying their time and they are getting love. I think it is much different than a standard zoo but it's also different in a good way. It is a non-profit and to me I think they are doing very good things for the animals and educating the children in our area. I noticed it might be difficult to get around for those who have strollers and or wheel chairs, they gravel is a little tough and there are some dips and holes, but I don't mind watching where I walk. I feel like they are spending the money on the right things. I think it's a great place to take children! The birthday party pavilion was great! It was very cool in there and plenty of space. The staff was super friendly and helpful! If I had kids I'd bring them back here often, I'd probably even take guests who are animal lovers here to visit as well!

The parking lot is not paved, but we didn't have issues coming in a car. Just something to keep in mind for those who have low cars, etc.
title: Austin Zoo

text: The place has a lot to offer. You have exotic animals like lions, tigers and Galapagos turtles, and the staff are friendly. All animals here are rescues, and the entry fee goes into their upkeep. The train ride is nice too. Great for the whole family!
title: Austin Zoo

text: I loved it! Not your typical zoo. It's rescued animals. But they were active. We had a picnic inside. And feeding the animals was fun for the kids. The train ride could've been better but it gave us time to unwind at the end. It's totally worth the time.
title: Austin Zoo

text:
Iâ€™ve been going to the Austin zoo for years, and I've always loved it. It's perfect if you have small kids- they have a petting zoo, peacocks walking around, an adorable train ride,  you can spend a couple of hours or less and that's plenty off time to see everything.
However, they have really gone downhill. The prices are ridiculous. I had no idea you had to purchase tickets online. They made my kids and I stand under a tree while everyone got to go through. I was finally waved over and able to pay. I felt like a naughty kid being punished. The bathrooms are closed down- two nasty porta potties. There is no longer much to see. I seriously donâ€™t think you get what you pay for.
title: Austin Zoo

text: We were not impressed. First off for 4 adults and two children 4 and under cost $100, which I donâ€™t mind paying if itâ€™s worth it. It was not! I understand they are rescue animals and I applaud the effort they have taken on rescuing these animals BUT most of the cages were empty or roped off, most of the paths were bare ground, we paid for the train ride for all 6 and I am not kidding we toured a wooded field were they had props set up we passed one cage with longhorns and I believe some emus. When we circled back we went by a few more cages, I believe 3 or 4 cages with a few animals in it. We were visiting our grandchildren and next time we will just go into San Antonio. I would rather just send this zoo (which I would not even call it a zoo) a donation to help them. We were there less than an hour and we had did everything to do.
title: Austin Zoo

text: I would give it a 3.5 since this is more of a rescue zoo and not a proper zoo. Had decent animals for a rescue place. Lion, Tiger, Bear, Zebra, Cougars, Llamas are the only big animals you can see here. Sad to see such giant animals in a small space though :( . We were fortunate to see a peacock dance with feathers open. It was not crowded on a Saturday with weather in 80's.
title: Austin Zoo

text: Weâ€™ve always had a positive experience here. Itâ€™s small and easy to navigate.  The kids all seem to enjoy the train ride. Boo at the Zoo is always a hit!
title: Austin Zoo

text: Stunning zoo with stunning animals. So much shade and there's something or someone to see in every direction. You begin to get to know each and every animal and want to come back to visit them again.
title: Austin Zoo

text: Great trip with the kids! Seeing different types of animals up close was an enjoyable experience. I questioned why they couldn't be released to the wild and a staff member informed me that because they had been domesticated from rehabilitation or as previous pets/rescues, they would struggle to survive. It's great they have a sanctuary for them and the kids loved seeing them!
title: Austin Zoo

text: We had so much fun at this little zoo. My kiddos loved seeing all the peacocks walking around. Their favorites were the big cats, which were mine too. Some of the animals actually look towards you if you call their names. We got the memberships and can't wait to go back.
title: Austin Zoo

text: Used to bigger zoos. But it was fun. There is not really a place to cool down except the gift shop. The strollers that are for rent are not much for pushing in the gravel. So bring your own bed l because they don't even have space to put anything in them.
title: Austin Zoo

text: I don't know what you call this place, but this does not look or feel like a zoo.  With most of the animals out of view and seem to be out of commission due to overwhelming sluggishness. Keep out tape or red fence tape everywhere.  All but one concession or vending was closed, with the only one being toward the end of the zoo exit.  So assuming you don't want anything to eat or drink until the end.  Oh and that will only be chips and drink.  Let's also keep in mind visiting will feel a lot like driving though a ton of backwoods away from anything city just to get here.  I feel like the zoo was an afterthought to the city.
title: Austin Zoo

text:
Summary: Affordable, well shaded, educational, fun
Power tip: visit in weekdays after 1pm to avoid the field trips full of kids

Details:
Excellent place to visit in the fall when the temps have fallen a little. The animals are more active when it's not hot as H-E-double hockey sticks.
Take the train for $3 per adult, totally worth it and the kids love it.
title: Austin Zoo

text: Having only ever experienced the hustle and bustle of "big" zoos, this was night and day better!  Just more relaxed and family friendly.   Kids loved the train ride.  The cages are still "cagey", but since the animals are all rescued and surrendered animals, that makes it far less depressing.  We had a fabulous time and will be back!  Especially loved feeding the goats and the free, roaming birds!
title: Austin Zoo

text: Nice place but really small. You can walk the whole thing in about an hour. This zoo is rescue only so not all of the animals are in tip top shape. Felt bad for the big piggy that they had. All in all a nice place to bring the family just know what youâ€™re getting yourself / family into before you come
title: Austin Zoo

text: Cheap, fun place to visit with kids. The facility has done the best they can to keep the animals and visitors safe during covid-19. Not a huge Zoo and a lot of things are blocked off but overall a great place to have a fun time!
title: Austin Zoo

text: A nice rescue center that is called a zoo. This place only has rescued animals but they have a fair share of them including lions, tigers and bears (oh my). Its an affordable trip that gives you a parenting opportunity to talk about the purpose of that zoo versus other zoos.
title: Austin Zoo

text: Went here with my 3 &1 year olds and it was just the best time ever. Getting to feed and pet some of the animals and seeing all of the others was just awesome. This tiny rescue zoo is perfect for kids. Sooooo happy we took the kids.
title: Austin Zoo

text: If you're expecting a large zoo, like San Diego or Fort Worth you'll be sorely disappointed. This is a rescue zoo, and it's a good one. They have a pretty good variety, you can feed some of the animals, and they have a mini train ride around the zoo. A really great place for families with small kids.
title: Austin Zoo

text: The front counter staff was Amazing! My wife took me here to use my new camera. She had gone before and the paths were always close with limited distance restrictions. However, they seem to be changing that. The glass In the reptile house was dirty. The trashcans were full and surrounded by bees. The animals seemed very healthy and well maintained. I will likely give them another try come spring to see what's new. The worth here is feeding the animals as a family in the friendly part of the zoo.They are super friendly and love attention.
title: Austin Zoo

text: This was our first time.  Keep in mind that the basis for this zoo is an animal sanctuary, so no giant animals here, although there is a lot of variety and some very good species on display.  It is good for the kids and very interactive with the animals that you can feed and the peafowl roaming.  The train ride was a nice conclusion to our day.
title: Austin Zoo

text: This is a cute little zoo to take your kids to spend a couple of hours but every time we go, we see less and less animals. The cages are all far away and covered so itâ€™s hard to see the animals, there is not a paved sidewalks so bring comfortable shoes and itâ€™s not wheelchair friendly. Parking is also a dirt driveway but itâ€™s big. You pay to feed some of the animals but last visit the bag was half of the size than the times before. The only fun thing to do was to feed and pet the goats and the llamas. Anything else was empty or unable to see the animal and it wasnâ€™t even a hot day. They have a gift shop with cute merchandise and theyâ€™ve a food truck that sells hot dogs and shaved ice. They have an area with picnic tables. They have a little train that goes around the zoo but youâ€™ve to pay extra $3 to ride it. But itâ€™s cute and the kids like it.
title: Austin Zoo

text: This zoo is AMAZING! You get to be extremely close to animals that are kept very far away at most zoos. Imagine being 3 feet from a black bear, lion, tiger, cougar, etc. You can walk up and feed llamas, deer, goats and more. All of this in a zoo that is a rescue zoo and is a non-profit organization. The only drawback for me was not knowing the animals stories. In a zoo that is a rescue zoo, I would like to know how/why each animal came there and where they originated.
title: Austin Zoo

text: Very casual zoo, no bells and whistles but you get pretty close to animals. Peacocks walking everywhere. Closes at 5 though, so be sure to arrive early - it takes about an hour for a full tour, possibly more with children and stopping for food. Be sure to check out the capybaras, they're really cute!
title: Austin Zoo

text: Beautiful place to visit with all family
title: Austin Zoo

text: Love this place! Don't expect a commerical zoo, this is far from it. It's a rescue for exotic animals and that's our favorite thing about it. My kids love the train ride and being able to feed the animals. Highly recommend!!
title: Austin Zoo

text: Great zoo, a rescue zoo which is funded by donations and zoo admissions! Very friendly staff, isn't very crowded, and and animals here are quite interesting. If you want to see peacocks... There will be no place like this - peacock paradise! They run wild around the zoo!
title: Austin Zoo

text: Had a great family trip here. All animals have been taken to a better home and life away from their breeder or backstory. I liked it here because it was cheap and we had a great time in general. The train was a nice surprise at the end.
title: Austin Zoo

text: It's not a zoo so much as a rescue and a zoo combined. It's not all concrete like so many zoos. It's like taking a hike through the woods, but with lion and tigers and bears! Oh my! They even have a little train now that they rescued from Zilker, and for just a few bucks they'll take you through the Texas Hill Country. It's gorgeous and you don't have to get all sweaty walking. And then of course there's the animals. They're well taken care of with clean enclosures. Plus there's chickens and peacocks wandering free everywhere. Which is a huge plus! It's a really great place for birthday parties. Kids love it, but then so do the adults. Go there!
title: Austin Zoo

text: Minus the fact that there are no paved sidewalks throughout the park, it is a really good zoo and a fun place to take kids and adults alike. Hard to push a stroller but the fun makes it worth while. Second time I have been and I will return many times again.
title: Austin Zoo

text: We always enjoy a stroll in the park while seeing the great animals! I personally love the fact that most are rescued and not brought! Plus they have free stroller for small ones.
title: Austin Zoo

text:
I would not call it a "zoo" as much as an "animal rescue".

I've been to several zoos and this was definitely different. The enclosures were small for the animals and many of the animals were showing signs of stress. The train ride offered is mostly through trees and shrubs, not a tour of the property, and it's not included in the admission ticket.

On the positive side, this place is small enough to visit without getting sore feet, and you can see lots of different animals close to each other. The property is also overrun by peacocks and peahens, so it was a neat experience to have them in such close proximity.

Overall, my kids found this place to be an interesting experience and liked putting coins in the donation boxes found around the preserve, but I would not come here again as I found it generally depressing to see the condition of some of the animals and enclosures.
title: Austin Zoo

text: The staff was friendly and helpful, the bathroom was clean, the animals were well taken care of. It wasn't crowded at all. The over all experience was better than most standard zoos I've ever been to.
title: Austin Zoo

text: Definitely different type of zoo.  First time going, kids loved feeding the animals,  we have many pics and videos,  priceless. One thing, wear tennis because the pathways are not made of cement.
title: Austin Zoo

text: This place is 15 acres of many different species of rescued animals. You can pet and feed llamas, alpacas, sheep and goats. There is a small food truck with snow cones, pizza, hotdogs and snacks. Restrooms are clean. Well worth the price of admission.
title: Austin Zoo

text: Love this place. Everytime we go we have a blast. Today, Gabby was stationed around the goats and deer (feeding area) and she was so sweet and helpful and friendly. I just loved her. Hope we run into her again. The train is always a must for the 4 year old, and the gentlemen running the train are always so professional as well. I want to praise them for running another train ride. They usually do them at the top of the hour, but there were too many people to fit on the train, so they happily ran a second ride right after the first. It really made our day. Anyway, the animals are always well taken care of. They got a new bearcat which I enjoyed learning about. They have discussions about the animals and ask the workers in the zoo know about them. Like we had to leave because it was basically a time, but someone stopped and told us about the turtle talk that was about to start. Have also let us know the train was leaving soon. I just feel like the staff truly love what they do and are always there to help you. The animals are all rescue animals, so you're contributing to a truly wonderful cause with every visit... I just love this so. Can't wait to be back!
title: Austin Zoo

text: Did a good job with making sure people wore masks and not too many families around to make it crowded. Plexiglass between the train cars. Kind woman working the gift shop gave every child peacock feathers. It was a fun adventure!
title: Austin Zoo

text: We loved this zoo! It's a nonprofit zoo, which is always a plus to us and they seem to take good care of their animals. I highly recommend feeding the Llamas, deer, goats and sheep! Super fun experience and inexpensive.
title: Austin Zoo

text: The Zoo is awesome, clean. Fun to see some peacocks wandering around. We like that it has rescued animals and their stories posted. The train ride is fun too.
title: Austin Zoo

text: Awesome zoo in a neat location.  Great variety of animals and thereâ€™s a train!  Train costs extra but totally worth it.  They decorate it for Halloween and probably some other holidays.  Wasnâ€™t very busy so we could take our time without having to worry about getting funneled through by other groups.
title: Austin Zoo

text: Excellent family retreat for at least half day of fun. Lots of exotic animals, plenty of natural shade and rest areas. Nice train ride the kids enjoy very much. Friendly and knowledgeable staff. A not for profit zoo do all proceeds benefit the entire rescued animals. Peacocks fly and strut around with their beautiful display. Can't say enough good about this special place. Go! Enjoy with your family.
title: Austin Zoo

text: This was an amazing place! We are in town for a conference and drive out there this morning to visit and we loved it! When we are back in town we will definitely visit again. It only took us about an hour at the Zoo. If my child has been with us it would have taken longer!
title: Austin Zoo

text: For a rescue zoo it was great. The animals were being well taken care of. Wide variety of monkeys and birds. A couple big cats. It's open 9:30-6pm M-F. They have deer, sheep, goat, and llama feed that's $3. And the train ride is $3.
title: Austin Zoo

text: This was our very first visit and we can't wait to go back. We saved a couple of dollars purchasing the tickets online. You're able to buy food pellets and feed the llamas, goats, and sheep ($3 a bag); this was our favorite aspect. They've also made the train ride rather special but I won't give any spoilers. The staff was beyond helpful and friendly. This zoo allows you to get closer to the animals which we loved. I find the San Antonio Zoo depressing and prefer Gladys Porter in Brownsville. This zoo has them both beat.
title: Austin Zoo

text: Very different than a big commercial zoo, but in a great way! Large habitats, not cages. Wander freely through the space rather than being shuffled along in crowds. Non-profit rehabilitation for animals rather than $8 soda and tons of people. No gimmicks, just animals. My family had a great time!
title: Austin Zoo

text: This was a really fun family trip to take the kids I was babysitting. We went in the morning as soon as it opened to beat some of the summer heat. For an adult and 2 kids (along with 1 bag of animal feed for each kid) it was $35. The zoo is well laid out and I love that they are a sanctuary for rescued animals. Make sure kiddos wear closed tied shoes (walking in dirt and rocks). Train ride was fun for kids but a lot of animals weren't out because of the heat. This would be fun in the fall.
title: Austin Zoo

text: The zoo staff is friendly and informative. My family enjoyed our time and I that these animals have been rescued or surrendered. I would love for the animals to be in their normal habitat but I'm grateful that they are being taken care of here instead of worse.
title: Austin Zoo

text: Beautiful location especially for a zoo! As others have mentioned,  this is not your typical zoo which our family loved. There are various types of rescue animals scattered throughout who all seem to be well loved and taken care of by the park staff. Visit with an open heart and mind, you won't be disappointed!
title: Austin Zoo

text: First time here, spent a great afternoon with my wife and granddaughter strolling around the park, and getting seriously up close with one of the lionesses. Superb variety for a smaller zoo, everything is clean and well maintained.
title: Austin Zoo

text: Small but mighty! This zoo was so awesome. I'm not sure what the exact thing is or more likely a combination of many things, but this was the most fun I've had at a zoo. The animals were very interactive with the humans. These animals actually want to to look at them and talk to them. And tons of peacocks and peahens. Please don't feed the wrong animals the food, you'll ruin it for everyone.
title: Austin Zoo

text: The zoo has a surprisingly large amount of animals, for being rescued animals. We were interested to learn that some of the animals were given to the zoo after their original zoos were damaged in hurricanes. The feeding area was a fun addition to just viewing the animals. My two year old nephew loved the short ride on the mini zoo train. The ride doesn't go by many animals, but It was his first train ride, so he was thrilled. Another fun part of the zoo is the wondering peacocks and chickens. Overall, a great little zoo!
title: Austin Zoo

text: Such an adorable little zoo! Its has a great mission. It's a non profit zoo that runs off of donations.  The animals seemed so happy. The place was clean besides the zoo smell lol. Didnt take long to walk the entire thing. They offer a little train ride. It didnt feel crowded at all. Plenty of space. Loved feeding the animals. Will definitely return one day. Worth the 3 hour drive!
title: Austin Zoo

text: WOW I havenâ€™t been here in YEARS and decided to take my little family on a Sunday. Great prices! Make sure you get there early at open time for best parking they have a team in the parking lot directing you where to park which is nice. It was very clean no trash anywhere and the Animals were wide awake to view! Plenty of staff around if you have any questions. Just a great fun Zoo experience its not a big zoo but itâ€™s still fun! They also do a train ride with a beautiful view and itâ€™s only $3 per person!! I would highly recommend
title: Austin Zoo

text: This is not your typical zoo , so if you get a chance to visit don't expect what you will find in the Bronx , San Diego or Cincinnati . This is more of a walk in the woods and its an animal rescue . I got a chance to visit looking for work and was surprised at what i found , Lots of nice trails that are well shaded and looks to be well taken care of . The animals there look to be happy , well fed and the staff was very polite and helpful. I will tell you to be cautious when visiting the lion exhibit ( The Males Spray )  So ... if you are in the area and would like a super time with the kids , go check these guys out ! text: Many animals. We started with the barn animals. Fed the goats, alpacas, deer, and some sheep. It took us a little over two hours to go around the grounds. I did the mistake to wear flip flops. title: Austin Zoo

text: One of my favorite places in Austin.    This is possibly not what you imagine when you think of a zoo.   First, this is a non-profit rescue.    The animals that here have been saved from a wide variety of bad situations -- private ownership, orphaned wildlife, other facilities that couldn't keep them...    Every animal here has a story.    Because the purpose is to provide homes for these animals, you won't find a lot of the "commercial" elements of for-profit zoos.    On the other hand, this is a place where you can quietly walk graveled, tree-lined paths and observe lions and tigers from only a few feet away.   The animals aren't as active on hot afternoons, so consider an annual membership so you can come frequently to catch them in their playful moments!
title: Austin Zoo

text: ALL of the animals are rescue. If that's not enough, all of them are in their forever homes here. Bring good shoes and the kids! This is an excellent experience for the little ones. They also have a train that runs at the top of every hour. Its educational and just plain amazing.

text:
We love this zoo! It is an amazing institution that provides a safe haven for animals, AND a chance for kids and adults to see those animals up close and personal.

It's critical to understand  that this is a rescue zoo, and much smaller than most zoos. It is situated in the Texas Hill country, and feels more like a ranch than a theme park. The weather makes a huge difference in how pleasant it is to be there, as well as how active the animals are - so time your trip accordingly.

title: Austin Zoo

text:
We were lucky enough to get a private tour thanks to a GHA/Omni Local Experience and really enjoyed meeting its Director, Patti Clark.The Zoo has the admirable mission of 'not existing at all' since without abused, injured and abandoned animals to rescue, it wouldn't need to be here.

Patti could relay every story of each animal on our tour, and although many of its inhabitants were transfers from closed pet stores and zoos, the majority were exotic pets from owners who never considered what happens when a bear, panther or alligator grows up. This zoo is the final destination for these animals where they get to live out the rest of their days without transfer.

While there are no giraffes, polar bears or theme park rides, there's an enthusiastic and friendly staff caring for several hundred animals that otherwise most likely would have been euthanized. This non-profit is continuously building new enclosures and facilities and hosts daily programs and talks for kids and adults alike, in its effort to house animals from the 40-50 calls they get every month.

Austin Zoo is not a flashy place and doesn't have multi-million dollar enclosures and exhibits. You can see your entrance fee and donations in action, and the focus is on providing the best possible support for rescued animals. I'd strongly recommend visiting - kids will always love a trip to the zoo - but for adults the ethical mission is the real draw.
title: Austin Zoo

text:
A nice rescue zoo a short drive from downtown ATX.

title: Austin Zoo

text:
DONâ€™T GO IF YOUR CHILD WONâ€™T WEAR A MASK!

My friend and I and our four children, ages 4,3,2 and 7 months visited the Austin Zoo earlier this week.
The good: It is so classic Austin. Nestled on a hillside on the outskirts of town amidst lots of cedar trees, there were no paved walkways. I loved it. You can get through it in about an hour and feel like you didnâ€™t miss much, which is great with small children. They have a fun interactive petting zoo and peacocks roaming around all over. Love it!
The not-so-good: I confess most of this is due to my comparison experience with the zoo in my city- South Bend, IN (home of Mayor Pete Buttegieg). Our zoo is about comparable in size and number and type of animals. We also have no elephants, but we do have rhinos and will be getting giraffes soon. The surprising part of this is that South Bend is about a tenth of the size of Austin. I think maybe the Austin Zoo wants only rescue animals, and there arenâ€™t rescue elephants...I donâ€™t know. There are also a lot more cages at the Austin Zoo whereas South Bend has created much more natural habitats for most of their animals.
By far the biggest, most frustrating difference, however, was the mask policy. In the South Bend Zoo, and most places, you are only required to wear masks inside or if you canâ€™t social distance. (FYI I am VERY pro-mask, but within reason). This even includes the animal feeding area in the South Bend Zoo. In Austin everyone, including small children 2 and over, are required to wear masks even outdoors (which is the entire zoo basically) unless you are eating. On a windy day from 20 feet away the chances of passing on Covid are so low even the CDC wouldnâ€™t require this. It seems so unlikely Covid could be passed on to people or animals in that scenario. The Austin Zoo seemed possibly more concerned about their animals catching Covid than people, and I havenâ€™t read about animals becoming seriously ill with Covid.
Wearing masks for adults I do not believe is much to ask, but for my friendâ€™s 4 year old, she was very very upset, and refused to put one on. Children are not used to having to wear masks outdoors. Luckily they allowed us to stay as long as we promised to distance from the animals, but we were pretty worried we were going to be kicked out having seen almost none of the zooâ€”and tickets are NOT CHEAP. You even have to pay for 2 year olds. It goes without saying we didnâ€™t do the petting zoo.
So bottom line-great zoo, but donâ€™t go if you think your child will refuse to wear a mask.

text:

text: Beautiful little zoo, fun for the whole family!  We stopped by here it was a pleasant surprise! The price is very inexpensive $7 for adults, $5 for kids . There is no place to buy food only a small gift shop. Recommend bringing a drink or buying one before you start at the front gift shop! The giraffe/zebra area has a beautiful covered deck that's high above the ground. Highly recommend stopping there the view, breeze is very nice! Took us about an 1hr 1/2 to finish the zoo so it is very small but worth your time to check it out.

text: Small, well kept zoo thats perfect for toddlers or young children. It makes a big circle that takes about 2 hours to get through. The zoo lacks some big animals (rhino, elephant, lion). title: Frank Buck Zoo

text: Great little zoo with well kept animals. The zoo is really well kept and they have a really good variety of animals. Their cages were clean and they all seemed happy and well-fed. The whole zoo isn't very big but definitely worth the price. The customer service is what needs a little work. Some of the employees were great and very friendly while others seemed to be bothered by questions. I also didn't like that there was only one very small restroom in the very beginning. But, overall a great ace to visit for a few hours. Also, as everyone has noted the free castle playground in the front is a major plus. The kids loved running around in it after the zoo visit.

text:
This place is awesome for anyone starting your first fishtank to aquarists! It is not your typical aquarium store. There is a wide variety of fish, coral, and equipment for anyoneâ€™s budget ranging $-$$$.  There is saltwater fish upstairs and freshwater fish downstairs. Would recommend going on a weekday instead of a weekend to avoid crowds.

I cannot speak enough about the staff! Most of the staff have been there for 15+ years and are enthusiasts themselves. They never rush you and are always there to help you. They also love sharing info and care tips. Hunter was very friendly and helpful; we got to understand more of his specialty: saltwater fishes!

text:
Very nice selection with a few issues: Many of the tanks are mislabeled; the fish are a different species or don't have a label at all. The short woman with the bangs is very rushed and careless when handling fish. She seems to be annoyed with questions and customers overall. All of the other employees, however, are friendly and care about where/how your fish will be living.

Aisles are a bit narrow, and I doubt they're ADA compliant. Salt water tanks are on the second floor, which is only accessible via stairs. Pond area is nice. The parking can be tricky, but it's mostly shaded.

All in all Aqua-Dome is a decent local spot for fish and aquarium accessories.
title: Austin Aqua-Dome

text:
At best, I'm a novice at the aquarium hobby. I've been setting up an aquarium and navigating all the intricacies that comes with setting up a new aquarium. In doing so, a social media aquarium hobby group recommended the Austin Aqua Dome as a solid, local hub for hobbyists. During my visit, I was greeted and invited to ask any questions I might have.

The building calls back to the "Keep Austin Weird" idea in both supporting a local business *and* being a wonderfully unique shopping experience in offering an infinite collection of aquarium related materiel to purchase- from fresh water to salt/marine, from ponds, to desktop bowls and extravagant custom aquariums. My overall experience was akin to me being a kid going on a great field trip like a previous visitor mentioned in their review.

Though I am still waiting to introduce fish to my aquarium, I was able to have questions answered about different live plants suitable to my experience and want for the type of fish community I'll eventually be keeping. I was introduced to a myriad of different plant varieties and they had a wonderfully diverse set of options to choose from. I ended up purchasing 5 plants of two different kinds and a wonderful piece of prepared driftwood for my setup. I also bought a plant solution to introduce and maintain for my water that promotes growth. Finally, because I look to continue my business relationship with Austin Aqua Dome, I purchased a one year membership that will likely pay for itself as my odyssey into this passtime grows. High fives all around and I can't wait to go back again and, if my S.O. doesn't kill me, maybe start a 2nd aquarium in the near future!
title: Austin Aqua-Dome

text:
Our experience here was awesome! My boyfriend and I did 'The Lost Ship' room. It was a Wednesday 7pm booking, so just the two of us took on the challenge without anyone else booking in. And we escaped with 90 seconds to spare!! Our guide, Captain Charles, did a fantastic job introducing the room to us with this whole back story to set us up. If you pay close attention, there are clues in everything he's saying as well.

The room itself was the best part. It was actually several rooms all joined together and from the lobby you had to figure out how to even enter the main room in the first placeâ€”super cool! I had never seen anything like that before. The puzzles were also really well thought out and interesting, using logic and problem solving (not at all abstract or random). Of all the escape rooms I have done, I would say that this has been the best experience I have had because of the attention to detail in the room, the quality of the puzzles, and the experience of being able to solve it with just the two of us.

The room is actually designed for at least 6 people, because it would have been helpful for others to take on and simultaneously solve riddles in the room. I'm pretty amazed we were able to do it with just 2 (but it was mostly because we had a few timely hints... big ones, lol). Awesome experience, highly recommend!!!

P.S. - This location has only this room (Pirate's Booty 2 - The Lost Ship), and the other rooms are in their downtown location. So don't be confused ^_^

text:
Typically I am quite skeptical about these corporate run places or attractions like this. Especially when they're located in a mall or something of that fashion. In my opinion they tend to be more of a gimmick than an actual fun and educational experience.
That being said, you should also know that if you're expecting something like one of those very large public aquariums that everyone raves about, this very much isn't that in any way shape or form (and that's okay). It is however much larger than what you might be anticipating if you're basing things on how the outside of the building looks.

I say all of that, to say this. Even though this place isn't of the caliber of many major city aquariums, it does have to some great qualities for what it is. I wound up here because my FiancÃ© and I decided it would be a good weekend adventure for the kids, and as it turned out, we were right.

One of the major perks right off the bat is the fact that they often are only taking guests that buy tickets in advance (at least this was the case while we were there), meaning it is much less busy than it would be if they were letting everyone walk up and buy tickets. I feel that this really made for a less congested and more personal experience with the kids.

I don't know exactly what I was expecting for the price of a ticket here, but I do feel like it was absolutely worth it, not only for the kids, but for the adults as well. There were certain periods throughout the experience that I think I was probably more excited to see a certain animal than my ten year old son was. The way this place is set up is basically you're in an undersea maze where you continue on, learning about and seeing all sorts of creatures, eventually ending up at the end (a.k.a the gift shop). There are also parts where you're able to interact and be hands on with certain sea creatures, and that was pretty entertaining as well.

There are not only quite a few creatures (both salt and freshwater) to take a gander at but also several activities for the kids to take part in during the whole experience. This place also makes it incredibly easy to be able to see everything no matter how big or small you are (you'll see what I mean when you walk through). You might even get the opportunity to see several of the creatures eat, which can be quite fascinating. Specifically the Stingrays, I mean have you ever seen a Stingray eat? Probably not, and you totally have the ability to here.

When all is said and done, should this act as a replacement for those gigantic public aquariums that many cities have? Absolutely not, but oftentimes not everyone has access to those places or those specific aquariums, and this would probably be the next best thing in my opinion.
The staff here is also friendly, professional, and seemingly quite knowledgeable about the sea creatures they keep, which was refreshing to see.
I truly believe that if you can separate the fact that you're not going to get the full "aquarium" experience that you might get at those other very well known gigantic aquariums, then you can truly have a great time here, especially if you bring the kids.

Buy your tickets ahead of time, and have a great time. Wander around the mall afterwards, what do you have to lose?
title: SEA LIFE Michigan Aquarium

text:
Great location to have an aquarium! The Great Lakes Crossing Outlets are still thriving, unlike so many other malls in the Midwest. Sealife Aquarium is right next to Rainforest Cafe, which is fitting.

There is a small gift shop, places to sit, interactive exhibits, and decent-sized and adequately cleaned bathrooms.

There isnâ€™t a food area, but with Rainforest Cafe and the food court, itâ€™s not necessary.

The price of admission was decent. Due to Covid, itâ€™s necessary to schedule your time slot. I appreciated the ability to choose a time, as we went on a Thursday at 11:00am, so we could take our time and not be â€œcrowded outâ€.

Weâ€™d definitely visit again. ðŸ˜Š

text: I thoroughly enjoyed my experience here. I felt like a kid and soaked up the atmosphere. It's so beautiful and serene. The lines to get in were wrapped around and there were several people who let their kids run around/into you and don't respect personal space. We have gone back twice now and I've learned something new or saw something cool every time we have gone. I am looking g forward to going back. I do wish it was bigger though!

text: I love this place! My daughter had her 3rd birthday here. They have huge and colorful fish. They are absolutely beautiful. text:
Much fun.  Take the advice of the person at the front desk who told us to take our time.  Meander through the exhibits slowly and search through the tanks to see so many things that you would miss if you go too quickly.

So many great sights even with COVID precautions that prevent some activities.  My favorites: large nurse sharks and stingrays, lion fish, puffer fish, sea anemone, jelly fish tank, sea turtles, huge eel, BIG lobster.

text: Its been three years since we last tookbthe 2 and a half hour journey down here. The tunnels and play area are closed because of covid; but the aquarium is still phenomenal. Clean, well lit, happy healthy sea critters. I love the touch tank. Our 11 and 5 year old love. Highly recommended.

text: If you know when youâ€™re going to visit, you can get a discount on line. No waiting in lines. Of course, when I went there at noon on a Saturday, there was no line. Still, nice discount. text: This was a fun day for the whole family. There are crawl areas inside several aquariums for the kids to get a view from the inside (and a great photo op). The end is a very nice gift shop with things like pins at 50Â¢, mermaid tails, stuffed animals, to high end jewelry with aquatic themes. With your paid ticket you can re-enter as often as you want to on the same day. This aquarium is inside an outlet mall with a full food court.

text: We had a very nice visit.  We brought our  eight and nearly two year olds and they had a blast. text: My husband and I took our 5 year old son a few weekends ago.  We all really enjoyed seeing animals of the sea up close and personal. text: We love SeaLife, and visit regularly. It's not huge, but since we live locally and have a pass, that's a plus for me. title: SEA LIFE Michigan Aquarium

text:
SEA LIFE Michigan Aquarium is a great place to go.  The entry fee is a little high but in line with other aquariums around the country.  If they brought it down a little I believe they would see even more traffic and serve a greater part of the community.

The exhibits are kept neat and clean on the outside.  There were just two tanks they seemed to be having problems with but it was obvious they were working on it.  The staff was welcoming and engaged.  We had a slight difficulty at exit getting our â€˜free photoâ€™ when we were directed to go back into the line to get it.  That was worked out satisfactorily.

They have apparently been actively engaged in breeding and helping wounded wildlife but I did not see anything specific about that in the exhibits other than some numbers posted at entry.

They have a wide variety of sea life on display and they all appeared in good health.  Most of the displays had plastic plants in them.  It would be nice to see more natural environments for the creatures and to examine them.

The viewing tunnel was very crowded.  There was no docent there and several patrons took the opportunity to rest and enjoy the tunnel while a single line file of other patrons had to navigate through along with carriages and mall baggage they might have with them.

Overall this is an excellent location to visit.  The children enjoyed it.  I would recommend by passing the play area.
title: SEA LIFE Michigan Aquarium

great place to go see some very unique and cool looking fish and also learn some new things! Great for a class field trip and have a wonderful store at the end for all ur sea life fix!

text:
My family and I enjoyed the aquarium. There are a lot of great sea life to enjoy and some games to play. Older children would probably not enjoy this as much as the younger ones. Still a great experience and place to educate on all things water life.
As a person who has enjoyed many aquariums throughout the states, this one is very small when doing price comparison. If you use the coupons and discounts available (AAA, buy legoland get aquarium, or child free coupons) it is worth it. However the price without such is not worth it.
Example: (walk up pricing)
TN adults are $35 & child (3-12) $22
MI adults are $24 & child (3-12) $19
TN -We spent 4 hours exploring 2 HUGE buildings Sea & Fresh water life(could have explored longer too). Played several free games. Touched turtles.
MI- 1 hour exploring played 2 free games, and touched turtles.
Is it worth visiting? Yes
Is it fun? Yes
Just plan ahead and get those discounts. Do not think it is like other big ones. It will not take long to get through so add in that legoland funðŸ˜

text:
The Aquarium was lovely. My Daughter loved it. However, she was SO EXCITED to see Peppa. I didn't realize she was going to be there for only 15 minutes, & at the End of the attraction.  They made an announcement stating the section she was in (but we had no idea where that was. As we were at the begining) Anyway, I rushed my Daughter through in search for Peppa. We made it to the end by 12:12. Stood there, wondering where she was. At 12:14 I took a pic of her not there, & screeshoted the time on my phone. Another Mother with her toddler was also upset. She told me that was the whole reason they came. I think it's pretty crummy they didn't even do it for the full 15 minutes. Especially being that 15 minutes is not very long at all. With that being said. Again, the Aquarium was fun, but hearing my kid bring up that she didn't get to meet Peppa like promised the rest of the day stunk. â˜¹ï¸
**Edit: I did Email Sealife michigan as advised in their comment to this review. However, I haven't received any word back. So, thanks for trying to appear to care I guess?

text: Sea Life Aquarium is a great place to visit. It does seam a little on the small side; However, there are educational talks that take place several times a day. There are also feedings for animals such as the green sea turtles Benson and Carr. There are also feedings for the stingrays, green eel and bamboo sharks. If that is not enough, Sea Life also offers behind the scenes passes for only a few dollars a person. The passes take you behind the scenes where all of the magic and work goes into running an aquarium. The tour includes seeing where the animalâ€™s food is prepared, going to the life support system for the aquarium, the quarantine area as well as the lab where water testing takes place. There are a few animals not on display that are back there too, that only behind the scenes pass holder get to see. Sea Life Aquarium usually also has several events throughout the year. Usually offering bonus things for the kiddos. There are also promotions for first responders and teachers to get in free certain times of the year. As well as other offers. Sea Life is owned by Merlin Entertainments, last time I was there they offered deals for Lego Land, that Merlin Entertainments also owns.
title: SEA LIFE Michigan Aquarium

text:
Not sure why people complain about this place. We were inside for a little over an hour. We had enough time to see everything and it wasn't too crowded. The staff are extremely friendly and good with kids and happy to answer any questions.

We got a Groupon and it was about $26 for an adult and 1 kid, total. They also have various coupons online and you can combine prices with Legoland for a larger discount. We went the cheap route and just went to Sea Life.

We bought the $5 Mission Pack and my nephew (7 yo) was super excited to find all of the stamps and get his little badge of completion. They even have a little play area (think McDonald's play area size) at the end of the tour, in addition to various simple games throughout the whole place.

Nephew's Review: "Uh I like Sea Life. It's one of my favorite uhh fishing museums I've ever went to. Fart. Don't add that fart there. Don't add it."

text:
We have gone to SeaLife several times, and each experience has been different. If you're able to go on a weekday, it is less busy, and more enjoyable if you like to stop and read about various things or even talk to an employee about different species. Weekends are okay, but more crowded, and I think the employees are less able to talk. Anyway, we have done the "behind the scenes" tour which was cool, it wasn't the most exciting thing, but maybe for someone considering marine biology it would be. The critters here are all well cared for, and each visit, I have noticed how consistent they are with keeping things clean. If you are in the area, I would definitely stop! It is a little expensive, but it's cheaper than a trip to Chicago and I cannot think of another aquarium that is close. If you visit, take your time, I got to see a stingray do something like a dolphin move- "dancing" on the water.
Enjoy!
